{{tone|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox film | name = Die Stadt ohne Juden | image = The City Without Jews (film).jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Hans Karl Breslauer]] | producer = Walterskirchen und Bittner | writer = {{plainlist| * H. K. Breslauer * [[Ida Jenbach]] }} | based on = {{based on|''Die Stadt ohne Juden''|[[Hugo Bettauer]]}} | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Johannes Riemann]] * [[Eugen Neufeld]] * [[Hans Moser (actor)|Hans Moser]] * Anny Milety }} | music = [[Gerhard Gruber (musician)|Gerhard Gruber]] (new arrangement 2000) | cinematography = Hugo Eywo | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1924|7|25|df=y}} | runtime = 80 minutes | country = Austria | language = German | budget = | gross = }} '''''Die Stadt ohne Juden''''' (''The City Without Jews'') is a 1924 Austrian [[Expressionist]] film by [[H. K. Breslauer]], based on the book of the same title by [[Hugo Bettauer]]. The film is one of the few surviving Expressionist films from Austria and has therefore been well researched.<ref name="medienimpulse">{{cite journal |first=Thomas |last=Ballhausen |first2=Günter |last2=Krenn |title=(Alb)Traumhaft: Die Stadt ohne Juden |journal=Medienimpulse |volume=57 |date=September 2006 |pages=35–39 |url=http://www.mediamanual.at/mediamanual/themen/pdf/sicherheit/57_Ballhausen-Krenn-Die_unheimliche_Leinwand.pdf |accessdate=19 January 2008 }}</ref> The film was first shown on 25 July 1924 in [[Vienna]].
In his novel, published in 1922, Hugo Bettauer succeeded in creating a relatively accurate allegorical vision of the near future, although the book was intended as entertainment and as a satirical response to the primitive [[antisemitism]] of the 1920s. It immediately became Bettauer's most popular work: it was translated into several languages, and sold over a quarter of a million copies. Shortly after the premiere of the film Hugo Bettauer was murdered by [[Otto Rothstock]], a former member of the [[Nazi Party]], who was lionized by the antisemitic Austrian masses and was released less than two years after having been committed to a psychiatric institution.<ref name=Columbia>{{cite journal|author=Alexander P. Moulton|title=A Wary Silence: Karl Kraus in Interwar Vienna|journal=The Columbia Historical Review|volume=2|date=Winter 2002|pages=15–43|url=http://www.columbia.edu/cu/history/pdf/chr_vol2.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070317005326/http://www.columbia.edu/cu/history/pdf/chr_vol2.pdf|archive-date=2007-03-17|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
== Plot == In Austria the [[Christian Social Party (Austria)|Christian Social Party]] comes to power, and the new Chancellor Dr. Schwerdtfeger, a fanatical antisemite, sees his people as being ruled by the Jews. He therefore has a law passed by the National Assembly forcing all Jews to emigrate by the end of the year. The law is enthusiastically received by the non-Jewish population, and the Jews leave the country. But after a short time a sober reality makes itself felt. Cultural life becomes impoverished: in the theatres only plays by [[Ludwig Ganghofer]] and [[Ludwig Anzengruber]] are still performed. Many cafes are empty, or are converted into beer halls selling sausages. After an initial upturn, the economy declines, as business has greatly diminished, and has moved to other cities, such as [[Prague]] and [[Budapest]]. Inflation and unemployment run wild.
The political characters of the book (although not of the film, to avoid difficulties with censorship) are delineated in such a way as to be identifiable with real politicians of the period: Bundeskanzler Schwerdtfeger, for example, is based on [[Ignaz Seipel]]. Besides the political action, the film also dwells on the love relationship between Lotte ([[Anny Milety]]), a typical Viennese girl (''Wiener Mädel'') and the daughter of a member of the National Assembly who voted for the banishment of the Jews, and the Jewish artist Leo Strakosch ([[Johannes Riemann]]).
Towards the end of the film, the National Assembly resolves to bring the Jews back again. However, to achieve the necessary two-thirds majority, Lotte and Leo, who has already illegally returned to Austria with forged papers identifying him as a French painter, have to remove the antisemitic parliamentary representative Bernard (played by [[Hans Moser (actor)|Hans Moser]]), which they do by getting him drunk. The drama reaches a peak as he is committed to a psychiatric institution represented in Expressionist scenery, where in a claustrophobic and asymmetrically painted cell, he sees himself threatened by [[Star of David|Stars of David]].
This sequence also represents the divergence of the film from the book, as the action of the film is revealed as a dream of the antisemitic Councillor Bernard. This surprising turn of events was described in the original film program as: "In this moment of the highest distress Councillor Bernard awakes from his dream, finds himself in the tavern at a very late hour and says to the baffled Volbert: 'Thank God that stupid dream is over—we are all just people and we don't want hate—we want life—we want to live together in peace.'"<ref>''"Gottlob, daß der dumme Traum vorbei ist – wir sind ja alle nur Menschen und wollen keinen Haß – Leben wollen wir – ruhig nebeneinander leben"''. Kivur, Nr. 1346, o.J., o.S.</ref>
== Background == The film was made in 1924, about two years after the publication of Bettauer's novel. It differs from the book in several ways: for example, the city in the film is called "Utopia", instead of "Vienna". The film also has conciliatory happy ending, which is not only the exact opposite of the message of the book, but also represents a surprising and abrupt change of direction within the film itself, the whole of which is thus revealed as the dream of an antisemite who at last comes to the realisation that the Jews are a "necessary evil".<ref>''Die Filmwelt'', 1924, n. 14–15, pp. 6–7</ref> The reason for these fundamental deviations from the original was to reduce the controversial political impact of the content.
The film was Hans Moser's second cinematic role. The female lead was played, as so often in Breslauer's films, by Anny (or Anna) Milety, whom he later married (in 1925). The well-known Jewish actors [[Gisela Werbisek]] (billed as "Werbezirk") and [[Armin Berg]] appeared only in minor roles, as Kathi the cook and Isidor the commissionaire. The Expressionist backdrops and decor which characterise some scenes were the work of [[Julius von Borsody]].
Other cast members were [[Eugen Neufeld]] (Bundeskanzler Dr. Schwerdtfeger), [[Karl Thema]] (Cllr. Linder), [[Ferdinand Mayerhofer]] (Cllr. Volbert), [[Mizi Griebl]] (Volbert's wife) and [[Hans Effenberger]] (Alois Carroni).
== Performance history == The premiere took place on 25 July 1924 in Vienna, although there were still technical problems with the film. Bettauer and Breslauer, the director, fell out entirely, and Bettauer later refused to acknowledge any connection between the film and his book. The technically inferior prints of the film were often manually cut and shortened by the cinema owners themselves. Nevertheless, the cinema auditoriums were often full, although not only in Austria but also in [[Berlin]] (premiere 1926) and [[New York City|New York]] (premiere 1928, where it was shown as ''The City Without Jews''), it was very clear that the success of the film was not as great as that of the book. There were sometimes disturbances at performances: [[Nazism|National Socialists]] often threw stinkbombs into the cinemas; in [[Linz]] the showing of the film was banned.<ref name="korso">Heimo Halbrainer on [http://www.korso.at/korso/DStmk/bett.htm www.korso.at – Informationsmagazin für die Steiermark], July 2001 (page viewed on 19 January 2008)</ref>
A campaign of vilification against Bettauer was instigated, partly because of this film and partly because of his other activities. In the spring of 1925 he was murdered by a [[Nazi Party]] member, [[Otto Rothstock]], who was hailed as a hero and despite being found guilty of murder, was soon set free.{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}}
In 1933, the film was shown commercially for the last time, again causing a stir, when it was screened in the [[Amsterdam]] theatre ''Carré'' as a protest against Hitler's Germany. This copy of the film is presumably the same as the one discovered in 1991 in the [[Nederlands Filmmuseum]]. It was on a [[cellulose nitrate]] base and on the point of disintegration, as well as being incomplete. The German [[Bundesarchiv]] in [[Coblenz]] therefore made an "emergency copy", which was then reconstructed on behalf of the [[Filmarchiv Austria]] (Austrian Film Archive) by the company HS-ART Digital Service of [[Graz]] using the "DIAMANT" software developed by [[Joanneum Research]]; faded parts were then re-coloured.<ref name="korso"/> In October 2008, the film was made available on a portable medium for the first time as part of the DVD series ''Der österreichische Film''.
In 2015, a copy of the whole film in excellent condition was found in a flea-market in Paris.<ref>{{cite web |last=Noack |first=Rick |date=March 30, 2018 |title=Long-lost film that predicted rise of anti-Semitism has ominous message for today's world |publisher=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2018/03/30/long-lost-film-that-warned-of-rise-of-anti-semitism-has-ominous-message-for-todays-world |quote=The film — which sparked furious reactions in the mid-1920s — was believed to have been lost until a copy was discovered in a Paris flea market in 2015.}}</ref> The Austrian Film Archive organised a crowd-funding campaign to save the film to which more than 700 people contributed more than €86,000 (£72,000; $107,000). This full version of the film was digitally restored and re-released in 2018.<ref>(29 March 2018). ''[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-43569919 'Lost' film predicting rise of Nazism returns to screen]''. [[BBC News]].</ref>
== Critical reaction == "In many places the film follows the original book almost word for word, which makes the Utopian ending even more obviously an expression of appeasement. At the end the surprised audience learns that the entire dramatic action only took place in a dream, and thus never really happened. The on-screen happy ending, dictated by compromise, not only negates the meaning of Bettauer's book but also the very real antisemitism that it reflects. Instead it documents a by no means unthinkable and in no way dreamlike reality [...] This surprising turn of the plot, deviating totally from the literary original, which simplifies the action as the content of a dream, cannot merely be regarded as a simple dramatic exigency, but as a prime example of the Austrian soul's ability to repress. This naïve and perhaps crude experiment from 1924 can be taken as a forerunner of what was generally practised after [[World War II]] in the country ''ohne Eigenschaften''"<ref>An allusion to [[Robert Musil]]'s novel ''[[Der Mann ohne Eigenschaften]]'' (English translations as ''The Man Without Qualities''.</ref>(Thomas Ballhausen, Günter Krenn, 2006).<ref name="medienimpulse"/>
== See also == *''[[A Day Without a Mexican]]'': A 2004 film on the effects of the sudden disappearance of all Mexican immigrants in US life. *''[[Berlin Without Jews]]'', a similar novel likely inspired by ''The City Without Jews''
== References == {{reflist}}
== Bibliography == * Walter Fritz und Josef Schuchnig (eds.), 1991: ''Die Stadt ohne Juden. Materialien zum Film''. Österreichisches Filmarchiv, Vienna, (Schriftenreihe des Österreichischen Filmarchivs; Folge 26). * Guntram Geser und Armin Loacker (eds.), 2000: ''Die Stadt ohne Juden''. Filmarchiv Austria, Vienna (Reihe Edition Film und Text. 3.) {{ISBN|3-901932-08-9}}.
== External links == * [http://www.filmportal.de/en/movie/die-stadt-ohne-juden_ea43d4a706da5006e03053d50b37753d ''Die Stadt ohne Juden''] at [[filmportal.de|filmportal.de/en]] * {{IMDb title|0016392|Die Stadt ohne Juden}} * [http://www.iaslonline.de/index.php?vorgang_id=2265 Rezension von Guntram Geser and Armin Loacker (eds.): ''Die Stadt ohne Juden''. Filmarchiv Austria, Wien 2000] {{de icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/bettauer/stadtjud/stadtjud.htm Gutenberg.spiegel.de Die Stadt ohne Juden – Bettauer's novel online] {{de icon}}

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''The Five Senses'' (pair of paintings)}} [[File:Jan Brueghel (I), Hendrick van Balen (I) and Gerard Seghers - Allegory of Sight and Smell.jpg|thumb|350px|''The Senses of Sight and Smell'', 1618; copy c. 1620]] [[File:File-Bruegel d. Ä., Jan -The Senses of Hearing, Touch and Taste - 1618.jpg|thumb|350px|''The Senses of Hearing, Touch and Taste'', 1618; copy c. 1620]] '''''The Five Senses''''' are a pair of [[oil paintings]] made by [[Jan Brueghel the Elder]] and others in 1617–18, at the same time as he was working with [[Peter Paul Rubens]] on a [[The Five Senses (series)|series of five paintings]] on the same topic. The originals were lost in a fire in 1731; faithful copies dated to c. 1620 were preserved and are in the [[Prado Museum]] in [[Madrid]].
==Background== Brueghel, like Rubens, was at this time working in [[Antwerp]] at the court of [[Albert VII, Archduke of Austria]], and his wife [[Isabella Clara Eugenia|Isabella]], governors of the [[Spanish Netherlands]]. [[Allegory|Allegorical]] paintings representing the [[five senses]] as female nudes had become fashionable in the previous century, but Brueghel introduced the illustration of the theme by means of assemblages of works of art, musical instruments, scientific instruments and military equipment, accompanied by flowers, [[hunting|game]] and fish,<ref name=Suchtelen90>Ariane van Suchtelen, "8. Jan Brueghel the Elder and Peter Paul Rubens, ''Allegory of Taste'', in: Anne T. Woollett, Ariane van Suchtelen, ''et al.'', ''Rubens & Brueghel: A Working Friendship'', Exhibition catalogue, Los Angeles: [[J. Paul Getty Museum]], 2006, {{ISBN|9780892368471}}, pp. 90–99, [https://books.google.com/books?id=c1cGWlxdP64C&q=Senses#v=onepage&q=series%20depicting%20the%20Five%20Senses%20in%20the%20Museo%20Nacional%20del%20Prado&f=false p. 90].</ref> which was widely adopted by Flemish artists.
==History== The two paintings were commissioned by the City of Antwerp to be presented to the archducal couple, and were executed by "twelve of the best masters of [the] city". They were paid for in October 1618.<ref name=Suchtelen94>Van Suchtelen, [https://books.google.com/books?id=c1cGWlxdP64C&q=Senses#v=onepage&q=1636%2C%20when%20the%20paintings%20were%20listed%20in%20an%20inventory&f=false p. 94].</ref> In 1619 they were in the audience chamber at [[Tervuren]] Castle. In 1731 they were destroyed in the fire at [[Coudenberg]] Palace. The surviving pair are close copies by Brueghel, [[Gerard Seghers]], [[Frans Francken the Younger]] and [[Joost de Momper]];<ref name=Prado1403>[https://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/online-gallery/on-line-gallery/obra/sight-and-smell/ ''Sight and Smell''], online gallery, [[Prado Museum]], retrieved 9 September 2014.</ref><ref name=Prado1404>[https://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/online-gallery/on-line-gallery/obra/taste-hearing-and-touch/ ''Taste, Hearing and Touch''], online gallery, Prado Museum, retrieved 9 September 2014.</ref><ref>[[Klaus Ertz]], "La dinastia dei Brueghel / The Brueghel Dynasty", in: Sergio Gaddi and Doron J. Lurie, ed., ''La Dinastia Brueghel / The Dynasty Brueghel'', Exhibition catalogue, Milan: Silvana, 2012, {{ISBN|9788836624324}}, p. 33.</ref> they were in Spain by 1633,<ref name=Suchtelen94/> where they were housed in various royal palaces before becoming part of the foundation collection of the Prado in 1819.<ref name=Prado1403/>
==Description== The pair of paintings are unique in including copies of their own works by a group of masters of the Antwerp school.<ref>Van Suchtelen, pp. 94, [https://books.google.com/books?id=c1cGWlxdP64C&q=Senses#v=onepage&q=entire%20Antwerp%20school%20&f=false 96].</ref> In ''Sight and Smell'', the paintings in the background include ''The Healing of the Blind'', representing spiritual sight, in contrast with physical sight, represented by a magnifying glass. A telescope in the foreground and a hallway in the rear, lined with art works, leading to an open door into nature and lit from above by shafts of sunlight, also refer to aspects of this sense. The female figure epitomising sight is looking at her reflection in a mirror which is held up for her by a [[putto]], while the other female figure, representing smell, receives a bouquet of flowers from another putto. The dog represents an acute sense of smell, and the [[civet]], stenches.<ref name=Prado1403/>
In ''Taste, Hearing and Touch'', the central scene is a meal; a [[lute]]nist is playing and children singing, epitomising hearing, while one young woman strokes a [[mink]] in her arms, representing touch, and another is about to eat [[oyster]]s, representing taste. Details such as the [[clavichord]] and other musical instruments on the left relate to hearing, and a monkey is pulling the hair of a [[Cupid]], a form of touch. The room and the hall visible in the right rear display pictures which are also related to the three senses: ''The Annunciation'' and ''Minerva's Visit to Parnassus'' (hearing), ''The Dentist'' (touch), and ''The Punishment of Rich Epulon'' and ''The Wedding at Cana'' (taste).<ref name=Prado1404/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/online-gallery/on-line-gallery/obra/sight-and-smell/ ''Sight and Smell'', P01403], [[Prado Museum]] online gallery *[https://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/online-gallery/on-line-gallery/obra/taste-hearing-and-touch/ ''Taste, Hearing and Touch'', P01404], Prado Museum online gallery

revision.text:
[[File:The last Jew in Vinnitsa, 1941.jpg|thumb|''The last Jew in Vinnitsa'']]'''''The last Jew in Vinnitsa''''' is a photograph taken during [[the Holocaust in Ukraine]] showing a Jewish man near the town of Vinnitsa ([[Vinnytsia]]) about to be shot dead by a member of ''[[Einsatzgruppen|Einsatzgruppe D]]'', a mobile [[death squad]] of the Nazi [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]. The victim is kneeling beside a mass grave already containing many bodies; behind a crowd of SS and [[Reich Labour Service]] men watch.<ref name="pa5355"/>
==History== The photograph dates from some time between mid-1941, when [[Operation Barbarossa#Ukraine and Moldavia|the Germans occupied]] the [[Vinnytsia Oblast|oblast (region) of Vinnytsia]], and 1943.<ref name="pa5355">{{cite web|url=https://collections.ushmm.org/search/catalog/pa5355|title=Photograph Number 64407: German soldiers of the Waffen-SS and the Reich Labor Service look on as a member of an Einsatzgruppe prepares to shoot a Ukrainian Jew kneeling on the edge of a mass grave filled with corpses.|work=Collections Search|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> During this period there were numerous massacres of Jews in the oblast,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/about/institute/killing_sites_catalog_details_full.asp?region=Vinnitsa|title=Vinnitsa|work=Online Guide of Murder Sites of Jews in the Former USSR|publisher=[[Yad Vashem]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> including in the town itself on 16 and 22 September 1941 and April 1942, after which those spared were sent to labour camps and the [[Yerusalimka]] quarter largely razed.<ref name="pa5355"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/untoldstories/database/index.asp?cid=686 |title=Vinnitsa, Vinnitsa County, Vinnitsa District, Ukraine |work=The Untold Stories |publisher=Yad Vashem |accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.rtrfoundation.org/webart/UK-arch-d2.pdf |format=PDF |title=The Holocaust in Vinnitsa Oblast |last=Vinokurova |first=Faina A. |date=2002 |work=Jewish Roots in Ukraine and Moldova |publisher=Routes to Roots Foundation |pages=332–335 |accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref>
The photograph was circulated in 1961 by [[United Press]] (UP) during the [[trial of Adolf Eichmann]].<ref name="bulmash">{{cite web|url=http://digital.kenyon.edu/bulmash/1085/|title=2012.1.397 : "The Last Jew in Vinnitsa"|year=2016|work=Bulmash Family Holocaust Collection|publisher=[[Kenyon College]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> UP had received it from Al Moss (b.1910) a Polish Jew who acquired it in May 1945 shortly after he was liberated from [[Allach (concentration camp)|Allach concentration camp]] by the [[American 3rd Army]].<ref name="bulmash"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://collections.ushmm.org/search/catalog/vha3081|title=USC Shoah Foundation Institute testimony of Al Moss|publisher=[[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}}</ref> Moss, living in Chicago in 1961, wanted people "to know what went on in Eichmann's time".<ref name="bulmash"/> The UP copy was published over a full page of ''[[The Forward]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ouzan|first1=Francoise S.|last2=Mikhman|first2=Dan|title=De la mémoire de la Shoah dans le monde juif|year=2008|publisher=CNRS éditions|language=French|isbn=9782271067630|page=306|chapter=La mémoire de la Shoah dans le vécu des Juifs aux Etats-Unis jusqu'au procès Eichmann}}</ref>
Some later sources say that the original physical image was in an ''Einsatzgruppe'' member's photograph album,<ref name="bulmash"/> or removed from the pocket of a dead soldier;<ref name="Knopp2014"/> and that written on its reverse side was "Last Jew in Vinnitsa",<ref name="bulmash"/><ref name="Patterson2016"/> now sometimes used as the image's name.<ref name="bulmash"/><ref name="Patterson2016"/><ref name="Knopp2014"/><ref name="Sanneh2015"/>
==Significance== The photograph has become iconic. Some features are unusual among well-known Holocaust pictures: it was taken during the Holocaust rather than after its end, and presumably by someone complicit in the killing; it depicts ''Einsatzgruppen'' rather than [[Nazi concentration camps|concentration]] or [[extermination camp]]s; the focus is on a solitary victim rather than a multitude.<ref name="Patterson2016"/><ref name="gee2017"/><ref name="Rakitova2016"/><ref name="Staines2010"/><ref name="Wollaston2010"/><ref name="SollbergerBöning2016">{{cite book |last=Boehlke |first=Erik |editor-last1=Sollberger|editor-first1=Daniel |editor-last2=Böning|editor-first2=Jobst |editor-last3=Boehlke|editor-first3=Erik |editor-first4=Gerhard |editor-last4=Schindler |title=Das Geheimnis: Psychologische, psychopathologische und künstlerische Ausdrucksformen im Spektrum zwischen Verheimlichen und Geheimnisvollem |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=WgA-DQAAQBAJ&pg=PA238 |accessdate=5 April 2018 |date=2016-10-10 |publisher=Frank & Timme |language=German |isbn=9783732903016 |pages=238–239 |chapter=Geheime Botschaften in Bildern; 5 Entdeckungen bei genauem Hinsehen }}</ref>
The photograph has been reproduced, with different degrees of [[Cropping (image)|cropping]],<ref>{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316042954/http://www.yivoinstitute.org/digital_exhibitions/index.php?mcid=81&mid=196 |title=Nazis executing a Jew at the edge of a mass grave, Vinnitsa, Ukraine. |archivedate=16 March 2013 |url=http://www.yivoinstitute.org/digital_exhibitions/index.php?mcid=81&mid=196 |work=Images of the Holocaust: Photos from the YIVO Archives|publisher=YIVO Institute for Jewish Research|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> in many books and museum exhibits about the Holocaust.<ref name="Rakitova2016">{{cite book|last=Rakitova|first=Maya|title=Behind the Red Curtain|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oeGiDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT11|accessdate=5 April 2018|date=2016-11-01|publisher=Azrieli Foundation|isbn=9781988065229|pages=11–12}}</ref><ref name="Staines2010">{{cite journal|last=Staines|first=Deborah R.|year=2010|title=Auschwitz and the camera|journal=Mortality|volume=7|issue=1|pages=13–32|issn=1357-6275|doi=10.1080/13576270120102544}}</ref><ref name="Wollaston2010">{{cite journal|last=Wollaston|first=Isabel|year=2010|title=The absent, the partial and the iconic in archival photographs of the Holocaust|journal=Jewish Culture and History|volume=12|issue=3|pages=439–462|issn=1462-169X|doi=10.1080/1462169X.2012.721494}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/photo/2011/10/world-war-ii-the-holocaust/100170/#img02 |title=World War II Part 18: The Holocaust |last=Taylor|first=Alan|date=16 October 2011|journal=[[The Atlantic]]|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> Books include ones by [[Guido Knopp]]<ref name="Knopp2014">{{cite book|last=Knopp|first=Guido|title=Der zweite Weltkrieg: Bilder, die wir nie vergessen|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=xUmOBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT172|accessdate=5 April 2018|date=2014-09-10|publisher=Edel|language=German|isbn=9783841903358|pages=146–151|chapter=»Der letzte Jude von Winniza«}}</ref> and [[Michael Berenbaum]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Berenbaum|first=Michael|title=The World Must Know: The History of the Holocaust as Told in the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|year=1993|publisher=Little, Brown|isbn=9780316091343}}</ref> Exhibits include in Berlin at "Questions on German History" in the [[Reichstag building]] from 1971 to 1994,<ref name="Patterson2016">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/oct/25/tread-warily-when-you-try-to-enlist-the-past|title=A photograph seen once, long ago, haunted me – and taught me to distrust memory|last=Patterson|first=Glenn|date=25 October 2014|work=[[TheGuardian.com]]|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> and then at [[Topography of Terror]]<ref name="gee2017">{{cite web|url=http://blog.smu.edu/studentadventures/2017/human-rights-holocaust-germany-2017/looking-for-answers/|title='Photography describes everything and explains nothing'|last=Gee|first=Denise|date=16 March 2017|work=SMU Adventures|publisher=[[Southern Methodist University]]|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref> and the [[Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe]];<ref name="memorialmuseums">{{cite web|url=https://www.memorialmuseums.org/denkmaeler/view/305/Memorials-to-the-Murdered-Jews-of-Vinnytsya#|title=Memorials to the Murdered Jews of Vinnytsya|work=Information Portal to European Sites of Remembrance|publisher=Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe|pages=Tab "Victims" |nopp=Y|language=English and German|accessdate=5 April 2018|location=Berlin}}</ref> the [[Institute of National Remembrance]] in Poland;<ref name="memorialmuseums"/> the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]];<ref name="pa5355"/> and [[Yad Vashem]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yadvashem.org/holocaust/this-month/july/1941-3.html|title=July 1941, a Member of the Waffen-SS Shoots a Jew at a Mass Grave in Vinnitsa, Ukraine|work=Yad Vashem Photo Archives|publisher=Yad Vashem|pages=2626/4 |nopp=Y|accessdate=5 April 2018}}</ref>
The photograph was used on the cover of [[Agnostic Front]]'s 1984 album ''[[Victim in Pain]]'', in an ambiguous reference to the [[Nazi chic]] then part of the [[New York hardcore]] scene.<ref name="Sanneh2015">{{cite journal|last=Sanneh|first=Kalefa|date=9 March 2015|title=United Blood: How hardcore conquered New York.|journal=[[The New Yorker]]|pages=82–89: 86|url=https://archive.org/stream/The_New_Yorker_March_9_2015_USA#page/n87}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Last Jew in Vinnitsa}} [[Category:Holocaust historical documents]] [[Category:Black-and-white photographs]] [[Category:World War II massacres]] [[Category:Military history of Germany during World War II]] [[Category:Military history of Ukraine during World War II]] [[Category:The Holocaust in Ukraine]] [[Category:Reichskommissariat Ukraine]] [[Category:Einsatzgruppen]] [[Category:1940s photographs]] [[Category:Holocaust photographs]] [[Category:History of Vinnytsia]] [[Category:Unidentified people]] [[Category:1940s deaths]] [[Category:People from Vinnytsia]] [[Category:Jewish people who died in the Holocaust]] [[Category:People notable for being the subject of a specific photograph]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} A '''tip sheet''' is a publication containing the latest information, [[tipster|tips]] or predictions for a particular industry. Tip sheets are commonly published to impart business or stock market information, music industry songwriter leads, and tips on [[horse racing]] results.
==Types of tip sheet== In the financial sector tip sheet newsletters offer investors' advice on [[stock and flow|stocks]]. In the UK, tip sheets are regulated by the [[Financial Conduct Authority]] (FCA) since 2010 to prevent malpractice. In prior to 2010, Financial Service Authority (FSA) also regulated.
Media tip sheets are typically lists of tips on how to do something, or solve a particular problem, that are printed in newspapers and magazines and appear on television. An example tip sheet might be titled "8 Tax Tips the [[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] Wishes You Didn't Know". They offer their creators free publicity and provide media outlets with free ready-made content, which they can reprint verbatim.
==Music tip sheets== A music tip sheet, or song tip sheet, is a research service that regularly publishes information about which [[musician|recording artists]] and film and TV projects are looking for music, along with the appropriate contact information. They are used by songwriters, publishers and record producers, but most commonly by new songwriters looking to gain a foothold in the industry.<ref name="emusician">{{cite web |url=http://emusician.com/tutorials/columns/pitching_songs_how/ |title=How to pitch your songs to industry insiders. |publisher=EMusician |date=1 July 2007 |accessdate=25 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724185818/http://emusician.com/tutorials/columns/pitching_songs_how/ |archivedate=24 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Songwriter, publisher and "respected music industry veteran" Eric Beall<ref name="berkleemusic.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.berkleemusic.com/school/faculty-member?person_id=1176543 |title=Eric Beall – Music Business |publisher=berkleemusic.com |accessdate=31 August 2010}}</ref> said that "If I were going to spend money on anything when I started out as a songwriter, other than the actual demos, I would put it into tip sheets."<ref name="hitquarters">{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_Eric_Beall_Interview.html |title=Interview with Eric Beall |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=7 April 2008 |accessdate=31 August 2010}}</ref>
Established music tip sheets include "RowFax", the [[MusicRow]] publication, and [[SongQuarters]].

{{Notability|film|date=August 2009}} {{Infobox film | name = World Builder | image = | writer = [[Bruce Branit]] | starring = [[Erin McGrane]]
[[Brian Paulette]] | director = [[Bruce Branit]] | country = United States | language = }} '''''World Builder''''' is a 2007 [[short film|short]] [[sci-fi film]] by [[Bruce Branit]]. The entire film (except for two characters) is [[computer graphics|computer generated]]. ==Plot== The film begins with the words "Program Start." In a [[green room]], a young man is lying on his back and looking at [[holographic]] pictures of himself and a young woman, presumably his wife (as we see a wedding ring on his hand). All of a sudden, a holographic timer appears on his arm, letting him know that something will happen in one hour. Closing the pictures, he stands up and gets to work. Using a [[computer program]], he begins to make a row of tall [[box]]es. Once the first row is made, he makes a copy and puts the copy of the row of boxes across from the first. He then gets to work on adding details to each box. He adds columns, doors, and windows. Once done, he works on the appearances of the boxes to make them look like [[building]]s. He adds color and then some [[nature]]. He pays particular attention to a yellow [[flower]]. Soon, with time running out, he hastily finishes the details and hide in a doorway when the timer stops. With time up, the boxes no longer look like [[computer model]]s but actual buildings. A door opens and the young woman from the pictures, dressed in a [[hospital gown]], emerges. She is astonished by what she sees. She walks down the [[street]], looking at the buildings and their details. Watching from his doorway, the man realizes that he forgot to do one building and it looks like a model from a computer program. He prays that she doesn't see the building. She comes his way and he hides, watching her look at the yellow flower and smile lovingly. She leaves the street with a final look back. Once she is gone, he emerges and watches his world that he created dematerialize into a new picture. It shows the woman smiling at the flower. Choking back tears, he kisses her picture. The screen goes dark, showing the words "Program Ends". In a holographic recovery room, the young man enters. The young woman is lying on the bed, in a [[coma]] and hooked up to machines to monitor her progress. He kisses her forehead and drops into a glass of water the very flower she admired in the computer program. ==See also== * [[Virtual reality]] * [[Worldbuilding]] ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1419113|World Builder}} * [https://www.npr.org/blogs/krulwich/2012/03/31/149690219/weekend-special-what-if-your-fingers-could-create-a-world NPR: Weekend Special: What If Your Fingers Could Create A World?] [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:2000s science fiction films]] [[Category:2000s short films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films about telepresence]] [[Category:Holography in films]] [[Category:Worldbuilding]] {{short-film-stub}} {{2000s-sf-film-stub}}

'''World art studies''' is an expression used to define studies in the discipline of [[art history]], which focus on the [[history of art|history of visual arts worldwide]], its methodology, concepts and approach. The expression is also used within the academic curricula as title for specific art history courses and schools.<ref>i.e. the [[School of Art History and World Art Studies]] at the [[University of East Anglia]] in [[Norwich]], and the courses at the [[University of Leiden]].</ref>
== Terminology ==
There are several expressions related to World art studies which are often used as interchangeable. Kitty Zijlmans and Wilfried Van Damme<ref>Kitty Zijlmans and Wilfried Van Damme, ''World Art Studies''in ''Art History and Visual Studies'' in Europe: Transnational Discourses and National Frameworks, eds. Matthew Rampley, Thierry Lenain, Hubert Locher, Brill, 2012.</ref> provide some more specific definitions as following
* ''World art studies'' is a concept conceived by the art historian [[John Onians]] in the early Nineties as a new field of studies, global and with a multidisciplinary approach.<ref>John Onians, ''World Art Studies and the Need for a New Natural History of Art'' in "Art Bulletin, n. 78, 1996.</ref> The multidisciplinary nature of World art studies differentiates them from ''world art history'' and ''global art history''. The expression ''World art studies'' was used by John Onians to rename the [[School of Art History and World Art Studies]]. The concept of 'World art studies'' is similar to the concept of ''Bildwissenschaft'' or ''image-ology'' is equally multidisciplinary in its approach to analysis of visual images.<ref>Kitty Zijlmans and Wilfried Van Damme make reference to the publication edited by Klaus Sachs-Hombach ''Bildwissenschaft: Disziplinen, Themen, Methoden'', Surhkamp, Frankfurt am Main, 2005.</ref> * ''Global art history'' refers to the study of art in present and recent past with a focus on the art worldwide and interrelated phenomena. This definition relies on the distinction operated by [[Bruce Mazlish]] between ''global history'' and ''world history''.<ref>Bruce Mazlish, ''An Introduction to Glocal History'' in ''Conceptualizing Global History'', ed. Bruce Mazlish and Ralph Buultjens, Westview Press, 1993.</ref> * ''World art history'' refers to the study of art of the whole human history. A remark made to this expression is the use of the world ''history'' in singular (history and not histories); the use of the plural is preferred by [[David Summers (art historian)|David Summers]]<ref>[[David Summers (art historian)|David Summers]], [[Real Spaces|Real Spaces: World Art History and the Rise of Western Modernism]], Phaidon Press, New York, 2003.</ref> and [[James Elkins (art critic)|James Elkins]].<ref>[[James Elkins (art critic)|James Elkins]], ''Stories of Art, Routledge, New York, 2002.</ref>
